div.note: Who would have told Renzo, a few hours earlier, as his search neared its end and his moments of greatest doubt and decision began, that his heart would be torn between Lucia and Don Rodrigo?

And yet, so it was. On that short walk, the figure of Don Rodrigo blended in with all the cherished or terrifying images that hope or fear had set before him. The words he had heard by that dismal bed were caught between the yeses and noes at war within his mind. As he prayed for a happy end to his great ordeal, he also added the prayers he had recited over the dying man before the tolling of the bell had cut them short.

The octagonal chapel stood in the middle of the lazaretto, elevated by a short set of steps. Originally, it was open on all sides, with no walls or support other than pillars and columns: a perforated structure, in other words. On every side there was an arch between two columns. On the inside, the church proper was surrounded by a gallery of eight arches, one for each side, and topped by a cupola, making the central altar visible from every window of the surrounding buildings and almost every point in the yard.

Today, the building has been converted for other uses and the once-open façades have been walled in, but the original framework has remained intact, clearly indicating its former appearance and purpose.

Renzo had just started walking in that direction when he saw Padre Felice appear in the portico of the chapel and stand beneath the middle arch of the side that faced the city. A group had congregated before him in the central pathway, at the foot of the steps. From the friar’s posture Renzo could already see that the sermon had begun.
Renzo made his way through the pathways to the back of the crowd, as he had been instructed.
There he stopped, quiet as a mouse, and surveyed the assembly. All he could see from that point, however, was an expanse of heads, pressed together like cobblestones.
Some in the middle were covered with kerchiefs or veils: This is where he stared most intently. Unable to discover anything in the crowd, he looked up to where everyone was staring.
The venerable figure of the preacher humbled and moved him, and, with all the attention he could spare at a moment of such great expectation, Renzo began to listen to his sermon:

“Let us pause to consider the thousands upon thousands who departed in that direction.” The preacher pointed over his shoulder to the gate leading to the San Gregorio cemetery, which had been turned into a vast common grave in those days. “Let us look around at the thousands upon thousands who remain here, still uncertain of how they will leave. Let us look at ourselves, the few of us who are departing from here alive.
Blessed be the Lord!
Blessed in justice, and blessed in mercy! Blessed in death, and blessed in health! Blessed in His having chosen us!

Oh, why did He choose us, my children, if not to set aside a small population for Himself, redeemed through affliction and inspired by gratitude? If not so that we would feel more profoundly that life is a gift from Him, and that we should cherish it as we should all things that He has given, and express our gratitude through good deeds that we can offer up to Him? If not so that the memory of our hardships would make us more compassionate and helpful to our fellow man?

Those who have suffered, hoped, and feared alongside us, whom we leave behind as friends and relations, brothers and sisters. For those who watch us leave this place, may they be edified by our composure, while taking solace in the thought that some of us have departed from here alive.
God does not want them to see us erupt in a loud, worldly joy at our escape from the death with which they still wrestle.
Let them see us leave filled with gratitude for ourselves and prayers for them, so that they may know we shall continue to pray for their pour souls once we are outside.
As we take our first steps in this journey, may we begin a life filled with charity.

May those who have regained their former strength lend a fraternal arm to the weak. May the young support the old. May those of you who have lost your own children see the children all around you who have lost their parents. Become parents to them!
And this charity, by redeeming your sins, will also ease your pain.”

A dull murmur of groans and sobs that had been swelling within the assembly suddenly fell silent when the preacher placed a rope around his neck and dropped to his knees. The crowd waited quietly to hear what he was about to say.

“For myself,” he began, “and for all my brothers, who, through no merit of our own were chosen for the great privilege of serving Christ by serving you, I humbly beg for your forgiveness if we have proven unworthy of this great mission.

If sloth, the rebellion of the flesh, has made us less attentive, less responsive to your needs; if an unjust impatience, a sinful weariness, has made us appear before you looking irritated or severe; if the desperation of your need kept us from treating you with the proper humility at times; if our frailty has led us to do things that upset you, please forgive us.
By the same token shall God forgive your trespasses, and bless you.”
Making the sign of the cross over the congregation, he then stood up.
I have been able to report if not the exact words that he spoke, then at the least their sense and theme, although I cannot describe the manner in which he said them.

It was the manner of a man who said it was a privilege to serve the plague victims, because that is what he believed it to be; who confessed that he was unworthy, because he truly felt he was; and who begged for forgiveness, because he was convinced that he needed it.

But what about the people who had seen the Capuchins dedicate themselves wholly to serving others and seen so many die; who had watched this man who spoke on their behalf, always the first in his labors and first in authority, until he himself was at death’s door? Can you imagine the sobs, the tears, with which they responded to his words?

The admirable friar then took a large cross that was leaning against a pillar and raised it high. Leaving his sandals on the edge of the outer gallery, he descended the steps and began to make his way through the crowd, which parted respectfully to allow him to lead the procession.

Renzo’s eyes filled with tears, as if he himself had been asked to bestow that singular forgiveness. He stepped to one side along with the others and hid by a hut, waiting, with his body in the shadows and his head sticking out, his eyes wide open and his heart racing, but also with a special newfound confidence born, I believe, from the tenderness inspired in him by that sermon, and the sight of tenderness all around.

Now came Padre Felice, barefoot, with the rope around his neck and bearing the large heavy cross. His face was gaunt and pale, radiating both contrition and courage. He walked slowly but resolutely, like a man whose only thought was to help the weak, and who had found the strength, through hard work and discomfort, to shoulder the rigors required by and inseparable from his job.
Immediately after him came the older children: Many had no shoes, while most were not fully clothed, some in only a shirt.

Then came the women, almost all of whom were holding a girl by the hand and singing the Miserere in rounds. The feeble sound of their voices, the pallor and languor of their faces, inspired compassion in anyone who found themselves there as a simple spectator.
Renzo looked closely from row to row, face to face, skipping none. The procession was moving slowly, so he had ample time to examine every woman who passed.

They kept coming and coming. He kept looking and looking, but always in vain. He gave a rapid glance at the remaining rows: By now very few are left. Here comes the last row. All the women have passed by.
All had the faces of strangers. His arms hanging and his head leaning to one side, he followed with his eyes the last row of women before the men’s group began to pass by.
At the appearance of a few carts trailing behind, bearing convalescents still too frail to walk, his attention and his hopes revived.
The women were in the last carts of the procession, which was moving so slowly that Renzo was able to examine every single face. To no avail.

He examined the first cart, then the second, and the third, always with the same result, until the last passed him, followed only by another stern-looking Capuchin holding a stick, the group supervisor.
It was Padre Michele who, as I have mentioned, shared the leadership of the lazaretto with Padre Felice.
With that, Renzo’s cherished hope vanished, taking with it not only the comfort it had afforded but, as is generally the case, leaving him in worse shape than before.
The best he could hope for now was to find Lucia in a sickbed.

Yet as the ardor of his hope succumbed to growing fear, the poor boy clung with all his strength to that sad and feeble thread. He fell into line and walked toward the place where the procession had begun.

At the foot of the chapel, he knelt on the bottom step, where he said a prayer to God, or rather a jumble of muddled words, broken sentences, exclamations, questions, complaints, and promises. It was one of those speeches not meant for the ears of men, since they have neither the insight to understand nor the patience to listen to them. They are not big enough to feel compassion for such words without contempt.

He stood up, revived. He walked around the chapel, and found himself on a path he hadn’t noticed before that led to the other gate. A few steps away, he saw the fence the friar had mentioned, and its large gaps exactly as had been described. He passed through one of them and found himself in the women’s quarter.

Almost immediately, he spotted a small bell on the ground, the kind the monatti wore on their feet, and realized it could serve as his passport inside this area. He picked it up, making sure no one was looking, and tied it to his ankle the way that they did.

Then he set out on his search, a search that would have already been arduous because of the sheer number of objects, even if they had been another type of object altogether. He began to survey or rather contemplate new miseries, similar to yet so unlike the ones he had already witnessed. Although everyone was suffering from the same calamity, here there was a different suffering, a different languishing, and a different moaning, as well as a different form of mutual support, pity and assistance. And the observer felt a different sympathy and revulsion.
He had already been walking for quite a while without incident or results, when he heard someone behind him say, “You, over there!” apparently directed at him.
He turned and saw a commissioner in the distance raise a hand, point straight at him, and shout, “They need help over there, in the rooms. We’re done cleaning.”

Renzo immediately realized for whom he’d been mistaken, and that the bell was the reason for the confusion. He cursed himself for thinking only about how this identifier would prevent problems, and not how it could invite them. But how could he handle this man?
He nodded quickly at the commissioner, as if to indicate that he’d understood and would obey the order, and then disappeared from his sight, slipping off between the huts to one side.
When he felt far enough away, he decided to get rid of the source of attention. To avoid being noticed, he squeezed into a narrow space between two huts standing back-to-back.
He crouched down to untie the bell, his head leaning against the straw wall of one hut, when he heard a soft voice coming from within.
Good Lord! Could it be?
He held his breath, and listened as if his life depended on it…Yes!
Yes! It was her voice!…“Afraid of what?” she said softly. “We’ve been through something much worse than a storm.
The people who have taken care of us so far will continue to do so.”
Renzo didn’t let out a shout, but not because he feared discovery. He couldn’t breathe.

His knees buckled and his eyesight clouded over, but only for a moment. In the next, he was back on his feet and fully alert, more vigorous than before. In a hop, skip, and a jump, he circled the hut and stood at the door. He peered at the woman who had been speaking as she leaned over a cot.
She turned around at the sound of someone at the door. She looked and couldn’t believe her eyes. Was she dreaming? She looked more closely. “Oh my Lord!” she cried.
“Lucia, I’ve found you! You’re here! It really is you! You’re alive!” exclaimed Renzo as he stepped forward, trembling all over.
“Oh my Lord,” replied Lucia, trembling even more. “Renzo? What is this? How? Why?
But the plague!”
“I’ve had it already.
And you…?”
“Ah…me, too.
And my mother?”
“I haven’t seen her since she moved to Pasturo, but I hear she’s well.
But you…you’re so pale! You look so weak!
Are you really better?”
“The Lord has decided to keep me here on earth a little while longer.
Oh, Renzo! Why did you come here?”
“Why did I come here?” said Renzo, approaching even closer. “You’re asking why I came?
Do I have to tell you?
Am I not Renzo?
Are you not Lucia?”
“What are you saying? What are you saying?
Didn’t my mother get someone to write to you?”
“Yes, unfortunately she did.
What kind of thing was that to write to someone down on his luck, a boy in trouble, driven from his home, a boy who at the very least has always respected you.”
“But, Renzo!
Renzo! Since you already knew…why did you come? Why?”
“Why did I come?
Oh, Lucia, how can you even ask why I came?
After all our promises?
Are we no longer ourselves?
Do you no longer remember what we were denied?”
“Oh Lord!” exclaimed Lucia in anguish, clasping her hands together and looking up at the sky. “Why did you not grant me the grace of taking me to heaven…?
Oh, Renzo! What have you done?
Just when I was starting to hope that…with time…I would forget…”
“You call that hope? And you say it to my face?”
“Ah, what have you done?
And in this place! Surrounded by this misery! By these sights! Here, where people come to die! How could you?”
“The dying? All we can do is pray to God for them, and hope they’ll go to a better place. But that’s no reason, no, not even that, for the living to lead lives of despair…”
“But, Renzo, Renzo!
Think of what you’re saying.
I made a vow to the Blessed Virgin!…A vow!”
“And I’m telling you that some vows don’t count.”
“Oh Lord!
What are you saying?
Where have you been?
Who has filled your head with these thoughts?
Why are you speaking this way?”
“I’m speaking like a good Christian! As for the Blessed Virgin, I think I know her better than you do. Because I think she has no desire for vows that hurt your fellow man.
If the Virgin had actually spoken, that would have been a different matter.
But it’s all in your imagination.
Let me tell you the vow you should make to Her.
Vow that you will name our first daughter after her, Maria. I can make that vow, too. That’s how you’re supposed to honor the Virgin. Devotions like that make more sense, and they don’t hurt anyone.”
“How can you say that? You don’t know what you’re saying! You don’t know what it means to make a vow, Renzo. You weren’t the one in that situation. You don’t know what it was like, Renzo!
Go. Go now, for the love of heaven.”
She broke away from him in a fury, returning to her cot.
“Lucia!” said Renzo, without moving. “At least tell me, tell me, if it weren’t for that vow…would you still be mine?”

“You have no heart!” replied Lucia, turning away from him and struggling to hold back the tears. “You’d force me to say words that won’t do any good? Words that might be sinful and could put me in harm’s way? Would that make you happy?
Go now, please go! Forget me. You can see that we are not destined to be together.
We shall meet again in heaven, for our time on earth is so short.

Go. Try to let my mother know that I’ve recovered. God has always helped me, even here, and I have found a good soul here, this kind woman, who is like a mother to me. Tell her that I hope she will be spared from this disease, and that we will see each other again when and where God wishes…Go now, for the love of heaven, and don’t think about me…except when you are praying to God.”
She drew even closer to the woman’s bed, as if shielding herself from danger, like someone with nothing left to say and nothing more she wanted to hear.
“Listen to me, Lucia, listen to me!” cried Renzo, but did not move any closer.
“No, go now, for mercy’s sake!”
“Listen to me. Padre Cristoforo…”
“What?”
“He’s here.”
“Here? Where?
How do you know?”
“I spoke with him a little while ago. I spent some time with him. And a priest of his quality, I think…”
“He’s here? To help the poor plague victims, I’m sure.
But what about him? Has he had the plague?”

“Ah, Lucia! I’m afraid, I’m afraid that, unfortunately…” As Renzo hesitated to deliver the news that pained him, and would pain Lucia even more, she stepped away from the cot and came closer to him. “I’m afraid that he has it now!”
“That poor saint of a man!
But not just the poor man.
Poor us!
How is he? Is he in bed? Is someone taking care of him?”
“He’s up and about, helping others. But if you saw him, how pale he is, how he struggles to stay on his feet!
There have been so many who look that way, so many, unfortunately…there’s no mistaking it!”
“Oh, poor us!
To think that he’s right here!”
“Only a few feet away. Almost the same distance as from your house to mine…if you remember!”
“Oh Blessed Virgin!”
“Not much farther than that.
And to think that we talked about you!
He told me some things…if you only knew what he showed me!
You will hear. But now I want to tell you what he said earlier, his exact words.
He told me that I was right to come looking for you, and that it pleases God for a young man to act this way, so God would help me find you. And he was right. He truly is a saint.
Don’t you see?”
“But if he said that it’s only because he doesn’t know…”
“How can you expect him to know the things you did on your own, without following any rules or anyone’s advice?
A good, sensible man like him would never have expected that.
But you should have seen what he showed me!”

Then he told her about their visit to that hut. In the time she had spent at the lazaretto, Lucia’s heart and senses had hardened, and grown used to the most ghastly sights. Still she was filled with horror and compassion by the story he told her.

“And there, too,” continued Renzo, “he spoke like a saint. He said that maybe God wished to deliver grace to that poor wretch (what else could I call him now?), that He is waiting to take him at the right moment. But he wants us to pray for him together…Together!
Do you understand?”
“Yes, yes, we’ll pray for him, each of us where God has placed us. For He will know how to unite our prayers.”
“But I’m telling you his exact words…!”
“But, Renzo, he doesn’t know…”
“Don’t you understand that when a saint speaks, God speaks through him? That Padre Cristoforo would never have said that if it wasn’t so?
And what about that poor man’s soul?
I really did pray for him, and I will keep praying. I prayed from my heart, as if he were my brother.
But how do you think he will fare up there in heaven, poor man, if you and I don’t repair things between us, and right the wrong that he committed?
If you listen to reason, then everything will go back to the way it was supposed to be. What’s past is past. He has paid his debt down here…”
“No, Renzo, no. God does not want us to do wrong for the sake of His mercy.
Let us leave this matter in His hands: Our only duty is to pray.
If I had died that night, does that mean that Don Rodrigo might never have been forgiven?
And since I did not die, and I was released…”
“And your mother? Poor Agnese, who has always loved me, and who suffered so much to see us become husband and wife, didn’t she also tell you that you were wrong?
She’s made you listen to reason other times, too, because, sometimes, she has more sense than you.”
“My mother? You want my mother to advise me to break a vow?
Renzo, you’re not yourself!”
“Do you really want to know?
The two of you, you don’t know everything!
Fra Cristoforo told me I should go back to him and let him know whether I’d found you.
I’ll go now.
Let’s hear what he has to say. I think he’s going to say…”
“Yes, go to that holy man. Tell him that I pray for him, and that he should pray for me. I need his prayers. I need them so much!
But for the love of heaven, for the sake of your soul, of my soul, don’t come back here again to hurt me, to…tempt me.
Fra Cristoforo will explain it to you, and make you come to your senses. He’ll set your heart at peace.”
“My heart at peace?
Well, you can forget about that!
First you had that awful letter sent to me. Do you have any idea how much that hurt me? And now you have the heart to say the same thing in person?
Let me tell you loud and clear that I will never set my heart at peace.
Maybe you want to forget me. But I don’t want to forget you.
And I promise that if you make me lose my senses, I’ll never get them back.
To hell with my job, to hell with good behavior!
You want to condemn me to a lifetime of anger? Very well, then. I’ll live as an angry man…And that scoundrel!
God knows I forgave him from my heart, but you…Do you really want me to spend the rest of my life believing that if it hadn’t been for him…?
Lucia! You told me to forget you. Forget you!
How am I supposed to do that?
Who do you think I’ve been thinking of this whole time?
And after all that’s happened! After all our promises!
Is there something I did to you after we said goodbye?

Are you treating me this way because I suffered? Because I got into trouble? Because I was a wanted man? Because I’ve been homeless and sad and far away from you for so long? Because I came back to look for you as soon as I could?”
When Lucia was finally able to speak through her tears, she clasped her hands, raised her reddened eyes to the heavens, and exclaimed, “Oh Blessed Virgin, help me!
You know that ever since that night, I have never lived through another moment like this.
You helped me then. Help me now!”

“Yes, Lucia, go ahead and invoke the Madonna. But how can you believe that the mother of mercy, a person so good, would want us, or at least me, to suffer…all because of a word you let slip at a moment when you didn’t know what you were saying?
Do you really believe that she helped you then only to leave us in this tangled mess now?
Or is this just an excuse, and you’ve come to hate me? Tell me. Tell me the truth.”
“Please, Renzo, please, for the love of your dearly departed, stop.
You’re killing me…This is not my time.
Go to Padre Cristoforo. Give him my regards, and don’t come back here ever again.” “I’m leaving.
But don’t think I won’t be back.
I’d come back here if this were the ends of the earth.”
With that he left.
Lucia sat or rather sank to the floor next to the cot. Leaning her head against it, she continued to sob uncontrollably.
Her companion, who until that moment had been holding her breath, but watching and listening intently, wondered at the meaning of that apparition, that quarrel, that weeping.
The reader must be wondering who she might be. Once again, it will only take a few words to satisfy your curiosity.
She was the wealthy widow of a merchant, perhaps in her thirties.

In the space of a few days, she had watched her husband and all of her children die at home. It was not long before she came down with the plague herself. She was taken to the lazaretto and placed in the same hut as Lucia, who was just starting to regain her strength and consciousness after surviving the worst of the disease, unaware of the series of roommates who had come through her quarters. She had become ill when she was still at the house of Don Ferrante and had been unconscious ever since.

The hut was only big enough for two, and they struck up an intimacy, and bonded in their sickness, abandonment, and isolation among the multitudes; very soon, it was as if they had been living together for years.
Lucia was soon able to help her companion, who was extremely ill.

Now that she, too, was out of danger, they kept each other company and kept up each other’s spirits. They had promised not to leave the lazaretto unless they could go together, and remain together afterward.

The widow had left her home, shop, and coffers—all well-stocked—in the care of her brother, a commissioner on the Tribunal of Health. She was about to become the sad and lonely mistress of far more wealth than she needed to live comfortably, and she wanted to keep Lucia by her side, as a daughter or sister.
Lucia had agreed, grateful to her and to Providence, but not until she received news from her mother, and learned, she hoped, of her approval.
Since Lucia was reserved by nature, she had never uttered a word about her engagement or any of her extraordinary adventures.
But now, with such a great reawakening of emotions, her desire to pour out her heart matched her companion’s desire to listen.
Holding the widow’s right hand, Lucia immediately set about answering her questions, with no restraint other than her sobs.
Meanwhile Renzo was hurrying off to the good friar’s quarters.
After some difficulty and retracing his steps a few times over, he finally managed to make it back.
He found the hut but not the man. After circling and searching the area, he saw him in a shack, leaning almost prone over the ground to comfort a dying man.
Renzo stood there, waiting in silence.
Soon after, he saw the friar close the poor man’s eyes, get down on his knees, and say a short prayer.
When he stood back up, Renzo went up to him.
“Oh,” Fra Cristoforo said, seeing him come, “well?”
“She’s here! I found her!”
“In what condition?”
“She’s recovered, or at least she’s on her feet.”
“Praise God!”
“But,” said Renzo, when he was close enough to whisper, “there’s another complication.”
“Tell me.”
“What I mean to say is…You know how good she is, but sometimes Lucia can be a little stubborn.

After all our promises, after all that we’ve been through—which you know about—now she says she can’t marry me. She says—what do I know?—that on that awful night, she lost her mind and—how can I put this—made a vow to the Virgin.
It makes no sense!
It would be a good thing for someone who knows these things, and understands when to make a vow, but for us common people, who don’t know how to go about it…Can that vow really be valid?”
“Tell me, is she far from here?”
“No, a short ways from the other side of the church.”
“Give me a minute,” said the friar, “and we’ll go there together.”
“Do you mean that you’ll make her understand…”
“I don’t know, my son. I have to hear from her first.”
“I see,” said Renzo. He stood there, staring at the ground with his arms folded over his chest, still ruminating over the same uncertainties.

The friar went in search of Padre Vittore, and asked him to cover for him one more time. He went into his hut, came out with his bag on his arm, and returning to Renzo, said, “Let’s go.” Fra Cristoforo went first, heading toward the same hut that they had entered together a little while earlier.
This time he entered alone. A moment later he reappeared, saying, “All we can do is pray.”
And then, “Now lead the way.”
Without another word, they set out.
The sky was growing darker, heralding the imminent storm.

Sharp bolts of lightning pierced the spreading darkness, casting a harsh bright light on the long roofs and arches of the galleries, the cupola of the chapel, and the squat chimneys of the huts. Peals of thunder broke with a loud boom, echoing from one region of the sky to the next.

The young man pressed on, impatient to get there, paying close attention to the path. He walked slowly, however, so that his companion could keep up with him. Exhausted by his labors, aggravated by illness, and oppressed by the muggy air, Padre Cristoforo was struggling to walk, and kept raising his gaunt face to the sky as if to catch his breath.
When Renzo saw the hut, he stopped, turned around, and in a trembling voice said, “We’re here.”
They went in.
“They’ve come!” cried the woman from the cot.
Lucia turned, leapt to her feet, and went toward the old man crying, “I can’t believe my eyes!
Oh, Padre Cristoforo!”
“Ah, Lucia. The Lord has delivered you from so much torment!
How glad you must be to have always placed your hopes in Him.”
“Oh, yes.
But you, Padre?
Goodness gracious, how you’ve changed!
How are you feeling? Tell me: How are you?”
“As God wishes, and as, by His grace, I wish to be, too,” replied the friar serenely.
Drawing her to the side, he added, “Listen. I only have a few minutes.
Are you ready to confide in me, as you have other times?”
“You are still my father confessor, aren’t you?”
“So, my daughter, what is this Renzo tells me about a vow?”
“At a moment of great tribulation, I made a vow to the Virgin…to never marry.”
“Poor girl!
But did you not remember that you were already bound by another vow?”
“No, I didn’t…but this was a vow to Our Lord, to the Blessed Virgin.”
“The Lord, my daughter, appreciates sacrifices, offerings, when they affect us alone.
When we make them from the heart, of our own free will. But you cannot offer up the free will of another, to whom you were already bound.”
“Was I wrong?”
“No, poor girl, that’s not what I’m saying. On the contrary, I am sure that the Blessed Virgin appreciated your tormented heart’s intention, and offered it to God on your behalf.
But tell me, did you ever seek anyone’s advice on this matter?”
“I didn’t think I had done something wrong or that I needed to confess. And aren’t we supposed to keep quiet about the few good deeds we are able to do?”
“So there is nothing else preventing you from keeping your promise to Renzo?”
“I don’t know…something preventing me…?
I couldn’t really say…” Lucia replied with a hesitation that indicated anything but uncertainty. Though her face was still pale from the illness, she suddenly turned bright red.

“Do you believe,” the old man continued, lowering his eyes, “that God gave the Church the authority to remit or to retain the debts and obligations that people might have contracted with Him, depending on the greater good?”
“Yes, I do.”

“Then you should know that those of us entrusted with the care of the soul have the broadest powers of the Church for all who come to us. Therefore, should you request it, I can release you from any obligation, whatever it might be, that you might have contracted through your vow.”
“But isn’t it a sin to go back on, to repent a vow made to the Virgin?

At the time I made it with all my heart…” said Lucia, shaken violently by the power of an unexpected feeling that I can only call hope, and by the opposing force of terror strengthened by all the thoughts over which she had for so long obsessed.
“A sin, my daughter?” said the friar. “A sin to turn to the Church, to ask its minister to use the authority the Church has given him, and that the Church has received from God?
I have seen how the two of you were united. And if ever two people were united by God, it seemed to me that it was you. I do not see why God would want to keep you apart now.
And I bless whoever it is that bestowed upon me the authority to speak on His behalf, however unworthy I may be, and allow you to take back your word.
And if you ask me to release you from your vow, I will not hesitate to do so. And indeed I wish you would ask me.”
“Then…then…I’m asking you,” said Lucia, with a face now colored only by modesty.

The friar gestured to the young man, who was in the far corner, observing intently (since that’s all he could do) a dialogue that would have a profound effect on him. When Renzo came closer, Padre Cristoforo said to Lucia in a loud voice, “With the authority granted to me by the Church, I hereby release you from your vow of chastity, annulling that which might have been unadvised in it, and freeing you of any obligation you may have contracted thereby.”
The reader can imagine how those words sounded to Renzo’s ears.
His eyes shone with gratitude for the man who had uttered them, and he instantly tried, and failed, to catch the eyes of Lucia.

“Return now, with peace and security, to your former concerns,” the Capuchin went on to say. “Ask the Lord once again for the grace to be a good wife. And trust that he will grant you that grace in even greater abundance, after all that you have suffered.

And you,” he said, turning to Renzo, “remember, my son, that if the Church is offering you this companion, it is not to give you a temporal, earthly pleasure, which even if it could be whole and free of unhappiness, would still end in great sorrow the moment you leave each other. No, it is that the Church wishes to set you both on the road to eternal joy.
Love each other as fellow travelers, with the thought that one day you will have to leave each other, and the hope that you will meet again in eternity.
Thank the heavens for leading you to this condition, not through turbulent and fleeting joy, but through troubles and miseries, to prepare you for a serene and peaceful joy.
If God should bless you with children, then try to raise them in His light, and instill in them the love of Him and of all humanity. And then guide them well in all else.
Lucia, did he tell you”—and he pointed to Renzo—“who he saw here?”
“Oh, Padre, yes he did!”
“Pray for him!
Never grow tired of doing so.
And pray for me, too!
My children! I want you to have something by which to remember this poor friar.”

At this he removed from his basket a box of ordinary wood, sanded and polished with Capuchin refinement. “This holds the remains of a crust of bread, the first piece of charity that I ever received. That bread you have heard me speak of before.
I leave it with you. Conserve it. Show it to your children.

They will grow up in a sad world and in sad times, surrounded by the proud and the irate. Tell them they must always forgive, and forgive everything. And that they, too, should pray for this poor friar.”
He handed the box to Lucia, who accepted it respectfully, as if it were a relic.
Then, in a calmer voice, he asked, “Now tell me, who do you know in Milan?
When you leave here, where will you stay?
And who will take you to your mother, God bless and preserve her?”
“This good woman has been like a mother to me. The two of us will leave here together, and then she will take care of everything.”
“God bless her,” said the friar, coming next to the cot.
“I wish to thank you, too,” said the widow, “for the joy you have brought to these poor children, although I had hoped to keep my dear Lucia with me always.
But in the meantime, I will take care of her. I’ll accompany her to her village and bring her to her mother.” Then she added, in a whisper, “I want to provide for her trousseau.
I have far too many things myself. And I don’t have anyone else to enjoy them with anymore.”
“In so doing,” replied the friar, “you will make a great sacrifice to the Lord, and for the good of your fellow man.

I have no need to recommend this girl to you. I already see that you treat her as if she were your own daughter. I can only praise the Lord, who is our father even in the midst of afflictions. By reuniting them, He has given a clear sign that He loves them both.
Come now,” he then said, turning to Renzo and taking him by the hand, “there’s nothing left for the two of us to do here. We have already stayed too long.
It’s time for us to go.”
“Oh, Padre!” said Lucia. “Will I see you again?
I am better now, I, who has never done good in this world, while you…”
“For many years now,” replied the old man in a solemn and gentle voice, “I have been asking the Lord for a favor, and for one great favor: to end my days in service to my fellow man.
If he wishes to grant it to me now, then everyone who bears some love for me must help me to thank him.
It is time for us to go.
Now give Renzo any messages you may have for your mother.”
“Tell her what you have seen,” said Lucia to her fiancé, “that I have found a second mother here, that I will come to her as soon as I can, and that I hope, I pray, to find her healthy.”
“If you need money,” said Renzo, “I have everything that you sent me, and…”
“No, no,” interrupted the widow, “I have more than enough.”
“Time for us to go,” repeated the friar.
“Goodbye, Lucia…! And goodbye to you, too, kind woman,” said Renzo, unable to find the words to express his feelings.
“Who knows whether the Lord will grant us the grace for us all to meet again!” exclaimed Lucia.
“May He always be with you, and bless you,” Padre Cristoforo said to the two women, and he left the hut with Renzo.
Night was falling and the storm was about to break.
The Capuchin renewed his invitation to the young man to spend the night in his hut.
“I may not be able to keep you company,” he added, “but at least you’ll have a roof over your head.”
Renzo was impatient to leave, however, and had no interest in staying there any longer if he could neither see Lucia nor pass some time with the good friar.
The hour and weather did not matter to him; night and day, sun and rain, dawn and dusk, were all the same to him in that moment.
So he thanked the friar, but said that he wanted to leave as soon as possible to go look for Agnese.

When they reached the middle path, the friar shook his hand and said, “If—by the will of God—you do find the good Agnese, please send her my respects. And tell her, and all those who are still in Pescarenico, to remember Fra Cristoforo. Tell them to pray for him.
May God remain by your side, and always bless you!”
“Oh, dear Padre…! Will we meet again? Will we?”
“Up in heaven, I hope.”

With these words, he took his leave of Renzo. The young man stood there watching him until he disappeared from sight, then he walked quickly to the gate, and cast a last compassionate glance around that place of sorrow.

There was more movement than usual: monatti running, objects being carried, the entrances to huts being pulled shut, and convalescents shuffling to the huts and galleries, in search of shelter from the approaching storm.
